facts.text: The appellant was the tenant of certain land at Lahori Gate, Patiala, taken for the purpose of a firewood stall, which is rented land within the meaning of s. 2(f) of the Act.
The original owner of the land became an evacuee, and the respondent purchased the land from the Managing Officer; a sale certificate was issued in his favour on May 31, 1963.
The appellant thus became the respondent's tenant.
The respondent filed an application for ejectment of the appellant on a number of grounds, including that the respondent needed the land for erection of a residential house.

The Rent Controller held that the respondent did not need the land for running any business but only for constructing a residential house for himself; rented land could only be vacated under s. 13(3)(a)(ii) if needed for business purpose; dismissed the application.

The Appellate Authority allowed the respondent's appeal, holding that under s. 13(3)(a)(ii) landlord could evict for any purpose of own use; followed Municipal Committee, Abohar v. Daulat Ram; directed tenant to put landlord in possession.
The Punjab High Court in Civil Revision 1077 of 1966 upheld the Appellate Authority and dismissed the revision on July 15, 1966.
Appellant obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Interpretation of s. 13(3)(a)(ii) of the East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949: whether a landlord can evict a tenant from rented land if he requires it for his own use for constructing a residential house, or only if required principally for business or trade.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if the respondent requires the land for construction of a residential house, he could not be given an order of ejectment under s. 13(3)(a)(ii); the words 'for his own use' must be read as qualified by sub-cls. (b) and (c), meaning use principally for trade or business.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 13(3)(a)(ii) read with (b) and (c) of East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949

respondent_arguments.text: Under s. 13(3)(a)(ii), landlord may evict tenant from rented land if he requires it for his own use, regardless of the purpose (including residential).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 13(3)(a)(ii) of East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, 1949; Municipal Committee, Abohar v. Daulat Ram

court_reasoning.text: Sub-cl. (a) must be read with sub-cls. (b) and (c); 'for his own use' in (a) is restricted to use principally for business or trade, as otherwise restrictions in (b) and (c) would be meaningless.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presence of sub-cls. (b) and (c) qualifies 'for his own use' in sub-cl. (a) to mean business purpose, given the ameliorative nature of the Act protecting tenants.

court_reasoning.text: If landlord occupies other rented land for business (per (b)), or vacated rented land without sufficient cause after commencement of Act (per (c)), he cannot evict; this implies 'own use' means business use.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court in Municipal Committee, Abohar overlooked effect of sub-cls. (b) and (c).

court_reasoning.text: Act is ameliorative legislation to protect tenants from eviction; interpretation limits eviction to same purpose (business) for which land was let.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondent requires land only for residential house, not business.

holdings.text: Under s. 13(3)(a)(ii), landlord entitled to evict from rented land only if requires it principally for business or trade, not for constructing residential house.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Committee, Abohar v. Daulat Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Held that s. 13(3)(a)(ii) allows eviction for any own use; Supreme Court holds this incorrect as it ignores sub-cls. (b) and (c)

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Urban Rent Restriction Act, No. III of 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines rented land and grounds for eviction; court interprets s. 13(3)(a)(ii) restrictively to business use when read with (b) and (c)

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; view of High Court and Appellate Authority set aside; respondent not entitled to eject appellant under s. 13(3)(a)(ii) as he requires land for residential house, not business.

key_quotes.text: "the words for his own use in sub-cl. a in the circumstances must be limited... to use principally for business or trade."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding restricting scope of eviction ground

key_quotes.text: "We are of opinion therefore that sub-cls. a, b and c in this provision must be read together, and reading them together there can be no doubt that... the meaning there is restricted to use principally for business or trade."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains interpretive approach to the provision
